as you look at particular processes materials or

and then often we'll build alternative embodiments study them in various ways
so what i'd like to do just go through a vignette
of sort of quickly moving through some work that i've had the you know great collaborations in the

one so a long time ago when i had a lot more hair we worked with

and the the thing is when i think about of course at that time we were thinking about things like what were the applications at the time
er telepresence was really required high-priced hardware it required trained

what if it was low-cost robotics no training and the application was just hanging out and that was kind of where
that went but the inspiration also came from artists so things like for example
uh andy warhol silver clouds which are moving kind of floating
you can see almost blimp-like but very much about this embodiment and the spatial relationship
two later on i was at intel research and again collaborating with folks who were
largely looking at things such as the object you see here which is a small uh sort of sensor-based network they
were called moats sort of like dust modes but the idea was really looking at applications of
putting low-powered routing algorithms for ad hoc networking
and different kinds of remote sensing applications there's a lot of really fundamental science that went around how
to construct these and operate them but again my adjacency to that research
i saw something different in this device and we thought about it as something you could maybe wear and the idea was could you have sensors
and communicate to people using that kind of experience so this is a slide deck from that time
the idea was you would tap on this device and a remote person would feel a kind of
remote sensation of vibrating another experience that was possible was that you could stroke it one way or the
other and the rope person would feel it heating or cooling on the other end and
finally you could hold on it and it would capture your pulse and transmit it remotely to the other person
now when i did this it was pointed out that quote this is a stupid idea please don't do this
ever you know how this turned out there's other devices that we are now probably

really understand that you're doing something that's often awkward but you might be getting pushback but try to
stick with it that sometimes these things pan out now when i think about this of course
there's all these technical issues that i'm going to kind of leave aside it was thinking more about

and be a bit seductive you just say here's this and this you figure it out
and what i try to get at is sometimes you don't need to complete the narrative
for people you don't need to finish every single thing with the interface or the experience sometimes you do

looking at new form factors looking at form factors that were in sort of other objects these are some

the future okay as you know now this is something that just is there it's like about what 13 15
years later we just have this and that's really empowering to see that transition i remember doing the early studies
people didn't even know where to look for air quality data we also started attaching low-cost
sensors onto mobile devices this is uh again at intel reacher research with rj
hanaki and others and we um really pushed on this idea that these
sensors even though they were not as accurate could play a role into a larger data set
and now you know 14 years later the epa now uses low-cost air quality
sensors in its public product if you've used it or looked at it the air now and that's really empowering as well
also we looked at how we could attach these sensors to municipal vehicles
we worked with the city of san francisco and collected air quality data and explored it this is largely in

the exact same thing 13 years later the inspiration for this is as much
about the sort of science as it is about thinking through rachel carson's comment
um she wrote the silent spring and she says the more clearly we can focus our
attention on the wonders and realities of the universe the less taste we shall have for its
destruction and i think that kind of positioning about how to
get people to think about their world is really powerful four
energy we plug in we get power i did a series of collaborations with
james pierce who is now faculty at uw around thinking about energy as a material we don't think about it that
way we think about it largely as something we just get and it works and we don't really give it much consideration but what would happen if
we went in that direction and i'll give you a thought experiment so think of some loved one this is my
son many years ago imagine he's swinging on a swing some energy is collected during this
he brings us home and then you read a book to perhaps the light that
from that energy that he gave back to you and my question is is that different than just plugging into the wall
and my claim is that it is it's something that has it's emotional it's gifted from someone it was there was
labor put in there was effort there was a kind of aura about it that creates a different experience than simply
you know just plugging into the wall and of course when we talk about energy we talk about reducing consumption and how
to that's a that's a very great strategy but i would claim what about how we might collect it or share it
or um you know keep it in different ways and i'm fully aware that lots of little bits of energy does not an energy crisis
solve but it creates some new dialogues and some new inputs about where there might be opportunities
we made these artifacts these sort of energy mementos again you can think of small little ways to collect and save
energy imagine that you turned a hand crank from your grandfather
and perhaps after he passed away would you put that energy on a mantle is that of value that's something that has some
something that is about him and his life and some creative energy that he put into it and there's many other examples
we also made these energy parasites that we kind of intentionally designed to be from handcrafted material but they
actually captured energy in public places so you can see you could attach them to
a vehicle such as this headlight where you could just sort of steal energy from the headlight of a vehicle you could put
them in a water fountain where they might collect energy on a handrail where they could just sort of again siphon
energy from the handrail motion or on a public transportation such as the tram you saw
this is not free energy you're stealing it but it's pointing out these opportunities where there's places to
engage with energy sort of siphoning or sharing and that's when we kind of fast forward
what do we have now in our products we have a way to share energy just the last couple years most of our mobile devices
allow us to kind of swap energy and this was a lot of the discussion at the time and again people said i don't understand
this project it makes no sense why would someone ever share energy and a very short time later we do have these
products and now there's an idea of what would that mean you kind of leave it on the bus do you give it to friends and all the kind of questions we were asking
again i would say it's back to the aura as walter benjamin talks about the authenticity of a thing
is the essence of all that is transmissible from its beginning ranging from its substance duration
to its testimony to the history which it has experienced so everything that its experience has this sort of aura to what
makes things unique five
there was some work that i um was uh really proud to do with elizabeth goodman looking at familiar strangers
these are sort of real relationships with people you have in public they're strangers you don't actually
know them but it's a real relationship where you sort of mutually agree to ignore each other without implications
of hostility right so you ignore your friend that means you're pissed off you ignore your familiar stranger that's
part of the protocol again at the time we were looking at using technologies and bluetooth which
was at the time used for communication we used it to figure out unique ids kind

to think about that particular way of operating and this was visualizations on yes those

strangers around you now it influenced lots of different um

at the time people were trying to be about massive communication and sharing things this was intentionally a standing

folks like vito akanchi who actually had this notion of how you can actually do this

it's part kind of a computer science engineering class but it's also an art class to critique culture and the kinds

listens for misogynistic language and then flips the tie in your face slapping you so a lot of different projects

around this artistic lens because i think it'll lead to some interesting directions

now sometimes we're looking what's going on in the field what's at the frontier but
i'm also curious what people are hacking what are what is the punk community doing and i certainly
don't condone this but they're putting electronics under their skin they're doing things that i do not want
people doing but people get these kind of super powers of having magnets out of their skins and
things i want to think about wearable or cosmetic computing
as this open invitation to hopefully create a new dialogue about what wearables can be
beyond just pushing on traditional roles of what we think of beauty or gender norms
and how it could open up a conversation broadly about a more personal performative
and meaningful expression of self so what do we have now a lot of these
kind of things and they're largely kind of flat screens that we interact with

ultimate future constantly things telling you what to do
and i'm not claiming we have sort of a solution but i just want to put out some other kind of uh points of conversation
and one of them was a project that we did largely drawing from the google jacquard team and with a number of other
colleagues thinking about how we can look at clothing and other materials that have a woven fabric as an input but also in
this particular example as an as a output and that is these are not
emissive this is basically a kind of thermal change that's in the dye and it creates a very different kind of
aesthetic than glowing lights or things like that and it sort of points this idea that we
could change our clothing throughout the day that what you put on you know maybe this is how i look now
but after lunch maybe i lose these stripes or maybe i have polka dots or maybe something else happens i might
change the style i might change the way that i appear and we you might think well why would i
do that i kind of put on my clothes i don't want to do that you do it anyway you move a scarf around i might take off
my jacket but similarly we already do that online there's infinite number of skins and you
know emotes and all kinds of filters that we apply we're constantly manipulating our social appearance and
it makes sense we would do that through clothing so a couple other things one of them was
we thought how do we get around this power issue one one project we explored was thinking about using e-ink which is
a bi-stable material that doesn't require power how could you take images or things from the environment
and sort of put them onto your clothing and they would remain remember it uses simply the power from your phone
to actually have a wireless connection and then send data across it similar to how you do wireless
contactless payments now and you could sort of change things and we also looked at a number of different
clothing so you could have it in shoes and you could have it in shirts you could have it very overt or very passive
there's all kinds of different experiences the main thing was it didn't really require power and the interesting thing is if you really did want to
you could just leave your phone in your pocket and of course to receive power you could have these kind of animations so that was a fun thing to do
it also meant you could scale these things so we looked at how it would actually work as like a fingernail form
factor and how you might use your fingernails as a place for that data
those of you old enough may or may not remember uh this goofy movie total recall but

so we could do almost things like that that's somewhat close to where we could be
now a couple more things on on the wearable front here one is hair
i know i don't have hair i did used to have hair that's how it goes i forgot to bring my wig to really illustrate this
but hair is also a really interesting uh part of the body and we did a lot of exploration of looking at what this
means and there's a lot of i'm going to kind of move through it quickly but certainly it's a personal choice but
it's a public experience it signals a lot of individual identity
it also talks about a group identity it's malleable think about the choice of
length or style or color there's lots of ways you can configure it there's also
some shared ways that people touch and there's an invited way of intimacy around hair
there's also habits the way you touch your hair actually is a lot of non-verbal cueing and other kinds of
things and we thought how could we leverage that and one of the things we did is
we looked at how we could embed a technology that let you sense what you were through capacitive
touch in your hair and then we could create a color change through a thermochromic kind of process
through heating and then also we could create actual uh physical change in the hair styling and
i'll just hint at this because i'm not going to go into great detail but for example you might get a notification
you know to meet someone well your hair is going to respond and then you'll kind of feel that and of
course how are you going to reply you don't need to pull out your phone you can just perform various gestures that
we can identify with your hair and that will send the appropriate messaging so similar there's ways that we can
actually just decide either by your own conditioning or others that your hair
style changes and we could have more dramatic style hair changes there's a bunch of different things that we can do
that i don't really go into all the examples i'll just give you the more big public scale version we can actually
get your hair to do quite dramatic things there's no secret wires involved this is kind of how it plays out
now this is by no means a kind of wrapped up discussion of all the kind of hair interactions you could have there's
a lot of things that are brought across other cultures of how hair and the meaning of hair and the meaning of the signaling and there's a
lot of really great work you could still do with hair but at least the balance of the kind of experience is
broad and so the other thing i want to talk about is skin and i mentioned this
stellar project these are works larger ahead of john rogers lab really inspirational way of putting kind of
sensors on the skin we looked at how you could possibly do that with low cost sort of
craft style materials and the idea was to basically use standard
silk screening to create temporary tattoos that you could put on the body and you could have all kinds of
different experiences from you know capacitive sensing resistive
sensing strain gauges so now you don't really need to interact with your phone the sensing is right on
your body on your skin and of course you want to play games
the the point is that the skin can be an interesting sight to investigate and sort of send secret messages as well
we're also thinking about other kinds of experiences on the skin and one of those is clearly around haptics and how people

some mems technology and you probably won't even be able to see in this picture but
there's a small small tiny little almost millimeter sized actuator there that you can push on the
skin and feel and the idea was what happens when you have
haptics experiences at that scale i'll show you the best thing i could show you sort of a video and this is at a very
very zoomed up in fact you're going to see this disappear between the ridges of someone's finger print that's how small this is
so what does this do this does not warn you that you're about to like crash on your
you know bicycle or something it feels like very different experiences the user
studies that we've been doing have really told us that this feels like some like the air is brushing on the back of
your head or a small bug is crawling on you or something's tickling you and the main point is this opens up i
think a new vocabulary about what we could do with haptics beyond just vibratory cues and because of the scale
we see envisionments of how we can get this down to small size

industrial robot during open-ended fabrication tasks our system consists of the robot a
custom forced work sensor the desired tool and a projection augmented reality display
here we show the readings from our force torque sensor which are used to compute motions for the robot
inspired by workshop jigs this system can selectively constrain the user's motions depending on the task through
software to demonstrate a range of applications we showcase four tools that can be used
with the droid to use a hand drill with our system the user selects that option through the
graphical user interface and mounts the tool to the robot after the drill is loaded the ar system
projects crosshairs onto the table to show where the drill is pointing when the drill nears one of the virtual
